fields.descriptive_line: Costume for a female dancer in the Mazurka in Petipa's ballet The Sleeping Princess designed by Leon Bakst, Diaghilev Ballet, 1921.
fields.physical_description: Costume for a female dancer in the Mazurka in Petipa's ballet The Sleeping Princess designed by Leon Bakst, Diaghilev Ballet, 1921. Knee length dress with silver lamé bodice and upper skirt, painted with black 'scales' over a silver silk-satin mounted on a linen underskirt and short silver silk-satin sleeves. The skirt is supported on metal panniers (which are showing signs of rust) and a net underskirt. The neck is bound in silver lace with double silver epaulettes. The hem of the overskirt and ends of the sleeves were once bordered with green leaves on a wire frame but very little of these original leaves remain. Bands of gold lame trimmed with a heavy metal braid fringe hang from the waistband of the overskirt. The ankle-length silver silk-satin skirt has been appliquéd with large stylized silver flowers with silver swags around the hem. [Theatre costume] 'Polish' dress with silver lamé bodice and panniers painted with black 'scales' and short white satin sleeves. The neck is bound in silver lace with double silver epaulettes. The paniers are bordered with green 'leaves'. From the waist fall bands of gold tissue and fringe. On the ankle-length white satin skirt are large stylized silver flowers with silver swags around the hem. [Theatre costume] Jacket of white velvet with wide oversleeves, trimmed with gold frogging and buttons, the collar bordered with gold braid and the sleeves and hem trimmed with brown swansdown. The wide oversleeves are bound in gold braid and trimmed with gold tissue-covered buttons. [Theatre costume] Square-crowned Uhlan hat in silver lamé with silver braid. Around the edge are looped decorative knots which fall in tassels of silver fringe from the crown on either side.
fields.public_access_description:
Costume for a female dancer in the Mazurka in the Ballets Russes production of The Sleeping Princess designed by Leon Bakst, Diaghilev Ballet, 1921.

The Sleeping Princess was first performed by the Ballets Russes on 21 November 1921 at the Alhambra London the lavish costumes were designed by Leon Bakst, who also designed the scenery. 

Knee length dress with silver lamé bodice and upper skirt, painted with black 'scales' over a silver silk-satin mounted on a linen underskirt and short silver silk-satin sleeves. The skirt is supported on metal panniers (which are showing signs of rust) and a net underskirt. The neck is bound in silver lace with double silver epaulettes. The hem of the overskirt and ends of the sleeves were once bordered with green leaves on a wire frame but very little of these original leaves remain. Bands of gold lame trimmed with a heavy metal braid fringe hang from the waistband of the overskirt. The ankle-length silver silk-satin skirt has been appliquéd with large stylized silver flowers with silver swags around the hem.

It was worn with a square-crowned Uhlan hat in silver lamé with silver braid.
